docs.lead_paragraph: Many Americans are surprised at the speed with which assurances that immense federal surpluses were here to stay gave way to the reality of deficits. Some of us, however, aren't surprised; we're simply following a trail blazed in places like Richmond and Austin. In the 1990's most states had Republican governors; and they applied the same strategy -- using what-me-worry forecasts and bogus accounting to justify tax cuts for the affluent -- that the Bush administration applied at a national level in 2001. In both cases the consequences were predictable. The difference is that state governments are generally prohibited by their constitutions from borrowing to cover deficits. Eventually the federal government, too, must live within its means -- but spin and denial can delay the reckoning. State chickens come home to roost a lot faster. In other words, the state of the states is the shape of national things to come.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed column by Paul Krugman says current condition of states is shape of national things to come; notes National Governors Assn reports its members face combined budget shortfall of at least $40 billion; attributes this to mostly Republican governors who used questionable budget forecasts to justify tax cuts for affluent; notes Bush administration used same strategy at national level in 2001; says selective tax cuts in states were cleared with forecasts that made no allowance for contingencies, but with creative accounting; says now states must deal with effects of past chicanery even as they face recession, soaring health care costs and fiscal impact of terrorism; says as states go, so goes America (M)
docs.snippet: Many Americans are surprised at the speed with which assurances that immense federal surpluses were here to stay gave way to the reality of deficits. Some of us, however, aren't surprised; we're simply following a trail blazed in places like Richmond...

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans said it would add customers in 2002 instead of losing members as it had previously forecast, and its stock price rose 12 percent. The shares rose $3.51, to $32.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Oxford expects enrollment to rise 2 percent this year for employer health plans, it said. The insurer had 1.36 million customers in employer plans as of Sept. 30. Oxford had forecast a membership decline of 1 percent to 2 percent.

headline.main: OXFORD EXPECTS ENROLLMENT IN HEALTH PLANS TO RISE

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans expects enrollment to rise 2 percent in 2002; stock rises $3.51, to $32.75 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Other major economies around the globe may be seeing signs of a soft landing or an incipient recovery, but in Japan, the recession is beginning to bite hard. A big psychological blow came with today's announcement of a radical paring of Merrill Lynch's brokerage operations in Japan, with 20 of 28 branches to be closed and 70 percent of jobs eliminated. Just three years ago, the country was hailing Merrill's expansion here as a sign that foreign investment would help lift the country out of its doldrums.

headline.main: Bad News Keeps Coming For Japanese Economy

docs.abstract: Japan's recession appears to be getting worse; big psychological blow comes with announcement of radical paring of Merrill Lynch's brokerage operations in Japan, with 20 to 28 branches to be closed and 70 percent of jobs eliminated; Tokyo stock market has fallen by half in last three years, and Merrill's retreat spotlights evaporation of short-term hope for recovery; Yoichi Masuzoe, once influential ruling-party legislator, says by end of March there will be financial crisis; Japan's 15 largest banks have said they expect to lose $17 billion in fiscal year ending March 31 (M)
docs.snippet: Other major economies around the globe may be seeing signs of a soft landing or an incipient recovery, but in Japan, the recession is beginning to bite hard.    A big psychological blow came with today's announcement of a radical paring of Merrill...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,000 jobs and take a $65 million after-tax charge in the fourth quarter as it realigns service operations in its employee health, life and disability benefits unit. Cigna -- the third-largest health insurer in the country, after Aetna Inc. and the UnitedHealth Group -- said it expected the restructuring to result in savings of about $45 million to $55 million in 2003. Cigna, which is based in Philadelphia, said it expected operating income for the full years 2001 and 2002, excluding the restructuring charge and other one-time items, to be in line with previous forecasts. The $65 million after-tax charge consists of about $33 million of severance costs and $32 million of facilities costs, Cigna said.

headline.main: CIGNA PLANS $65 MILLION CHARGE AND JOB CUTS

docs.abstract: Cigna Corp, third-largest health insurer in country, will eliminate 2,000 jobs and take $65 million after-tax charge in fourth quarter (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Marsh & McLennan Companies, the insurance brokerage firm that lost 295 employees on Sept. 11, has agreed to contribute millions of dollars more to its own charity to provide extended health benefits to the families of its dead employees. The move comes in response to criticism from several surviving spouses when the company, the world's largest insurance brokerage firm, initially planned to offer them one year of health benefits. Other World Trade Center companies have offered survivors 5, 10 or unlimited years of health coverage. The company later agreed to extend the coverage for three years, yet that decision stirred still more anger.

headline.main: Insurer to Pay More to Victim Families Fund

docs.abstract: Marsh & McLennan Companies, insurance company that lost 295 employees on Sept 11, agrees to contribute millions of dollars more to its own charity to extend health benefits to families of dead employees; move comes in response to criticism from several spouses when company planned to offer one year of health benefits (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The insurance companies that stand to lose the most from the disaster at the World Trade Center are forming a united front in their legal battle over whether the World Trade Center's leaseholder is entitled to payment for one attack or two, one of the biggest insurers said yesterday. The big insurance company, Swiss Re, made its assertions yesterday in a statement about the insurance payout on the trade center. The leaseholder, Larry A. Silverstein, has said repeatedly that the disaster involved two attacks, and that he is therefore owed $7.2 billion in insurance payments. The more than 20 insurance companies involved have said that there was one attack and therefore that they are obligated to pay only half that, or $3.6 billion.

headline.main: Towers' Insurers Argue Payment to Leaseholder

docs.abstract: Swiss Re, insurance company that stands to lose most from disaster at World Trade Center, and more than 20 other insurance companies involved, form united front on issue of whether there were one or two attacks; leaseholder Larry A Silverstein asserts that there were two attacks and that he is therefore owed $7.2 billion in insurance payments, but companies argue that there was one attack and that they are obligated to pay half that amount (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many companies, alarmed by the increasing size of payouts to resolve harassment or discrimination claims by employees, have bought insurance policies over the last decade to protect themselves. But insurers, who offered cheap premiums and low deductibles to encourage this new line of business, now find that they underestimated the number of small awards that companies make every year and did not anticipate the growing size of jury verdicts, one-fifth of which are now for $1 million or more.

headline.main: Surge in Bias Cases Punishes Insurers, And Premiums Rise

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki is promoting a deal with legislative leaders and the largest union of hospital workers that would avert budget cuts to health care programs and pay for raises for health care workers, people familiar with the talks said. The higher salaries and benefits would be paid in part through a one-time $1 billion windfall to the state from the conversion of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield from a nonprofit insurer to a for-profit institution, these people said.

headline.main: Deal in Works To Raise Pay Of Workers In Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Certified registered nurse anesthetists are nurses who complete three years of advanced training in anesthesia that legally allows them to give anesthesia without a doctor's supervision in 50 states. But Medicare rules, which tend to set standards for all patients, require physician supervision in hospitals. In November, the Bush administration rejected a Clinton administration proposal to let nurse anesthetists work unsupervised in hospitals. Gale Scott spoke to members of opposing professional groups about the issue. Following are edited excerpts of those interviews. YES. Certified registered nurse anesthetists offer safe quality care to their patients. One indicator of that is that our malpractice insurance premiums have decreased 50 percent over the last decade. According to the National Practitioners' Data Bank, nurse-anesthetists made one-seventh the malpractice payments that doctors made in 1990 to 1997.

headline.main: On the Front Line in the O.R.
